page.title: 15 CASTLE CARY IN 1086.
page.content: According to the Domesday Book, there was land in Cary for 20 ploughs. This probably means there was enough land for about 250-300 people,using in the region of 2000 acres for farming.In 1086 Castle Cary was a flourishing place,but not a borough. The King's commissioners recorded that it had belonged to a Saxon King called Elsi!There were three mills on the River Caty's banks and they were quite prosperous.The commissioners report that there 23 villeins and 5 swineherds,the latter grazing their animals in the nearby forest. In the 12th century Cary came into the possession of the Lovel family.It is not clear if the Lovels built the Castle or if the earlier Walter of Douai was responsible.The castle site was excavated in 1890.Nothing remains today and it is little known.
